scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the office files Peter F. Geithner created and managed during his career at the Ford Foundation. The collection is arranged into record groups. Each record group corresponds to a different position Geithner held at the Foundation. Throughout his time at the Foundation, Geithner's work primarily concentrated on program activity in Asia, and his last position at the Foundation before his retirement was Regional Director of Asia Programs.
To date, the collection contains two record groups.
Record Group 1 documents Geithner's position as Program Officer in Charge of the Developing Countries Program from 1981 to 1987.
Record Group 2 documents Geithner's position as Regional Director of Asia Programs from 1990 to 1996.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.
This material was transferred to the RAC in various accessions between 2011 and 2023 and was ingested by the RAC as Accessions 2011:072, 2012:025, 2019:050, 2019:136, 2021:110, and 2023:017.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Asia Programs office originated in 1958 as a division of the Overseas Development program then called the Overseas Development/South and Southeast Asia. In 1966, South and Southeast Asia office shifted to the International Division program area as part of a Foundation reorganization and, in 1968, the office was renamed Asia and the Pacific. In 1981, the office became part of the Developing Countries Program. The Asia Programs became a full program area in 1989.

At various points throughout its history, the Asia Programs maintained field offices in: New Delhi, India; Jakarta, Indonesia; Dhaka, Bangladesh; Bangkok, Thailand; Manila, Philippines; and Hanoi, Vietnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group contains the office files Peter F. Geithner created during his time as Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program (DCP). Materials span from Geithner's entire 1981 to 1987 tenure as DCP Program Officer in Charge. The collection is comprised of meeting and trip files, subject files, and chronology files.

Meeting files document the work that Geithner, other Ford Foundation staff members such as the different Field Officer Representatives, and external individuals and organizations completed for organizing, participating in, and reporting on various Ford Foundation program meetings and other types of events and conferences. Trip files document Geithner's visits to various countries and Ford Foundation field offices as well as the visits he helped organize for individuals like Foundation Board of Trustees Members.

Subject files largely concern the Foundation's programming regarding China. There are also some more general DCP administrative and program subject files. The chronology files contain copies of correspondence Geithner sent throughout his time as DCP Program Officer in Charge.

Geithner's files provide insight into the Developing Countries Program's interest in and support of initiatives concerning economic development, agricultural development, child survival, and reproductive health in countries throughout Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East during the 1980s. They also document the Foundation's growing program activity related to China ahead of its opening its Beijing, China field office in 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains the meeting and trip files that Peter F. Geithner created during his time as Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program (DCP). Meeting files generally concern the review of the Foundation's actions regarding issues such as employment and income generation, child survival, and reproductive health in developing countries throughout Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East as well as the planning and organization of additional actions to support the study and tackling of these issues. The series also includes meeting files that document other types of events such as a meeting the Ford Foundation organized between different foundations and Indira Gandhi, the Prime Minister of India, to discuss economic development and grant clearance procedures in India. Trip files concern the different visits Geithner organized for himself and other individuals like members of the Ford Foundation Board of Trustees to various countries and Foundation field offices. Some of the travel advisory memos within the trip files provide insight into the political situations and trends of these countries such as the opposition to President Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines and the violence of Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso) in Peru.

Although most of the series' files were created during Geithner's tenure as Program Officer in Charge of the DCP, there does appear to be some material that was created just before Geithner moved from his previous position as Representative for Southeast Asia in the Bangkok, Thailand Regional Office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains a group of photographs taken during Ford Foundation Board of Trustees' Member Rodrigo Botero's visit to countries in East and Southeast Asia in 1985. Photographs were originally contained in a small album from Bangkok, Thailand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the subject files Peter F. Geithner created when he served as Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program between 1981 and 1987. It is comprised of two subseries. The first subseries contains records specifically concerning the Foundation's programming for China, and the second subseries contains records documenting more general DCP administration and program activities.

The bulk of the series is contained within the China subseries. During the 1980s, the Ford Foundation expanded its programming for China when diplomatic relations between China and the United States improved. The Foundation would later open its Beijing, China field office in 1988, and Geithner would serve as the Foundation's first China Representative. One file of Geithner's correspondence from that position is included at the end of the first subseries.
In addition to correspondence, the series contains memos, reports, notes, drafts, news clippings, and meeting materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The China subject files subseries documents the work led by Developing Countries Program Officer in Charge Peter F. Geithner regarding the Ford Foundation's programming for China in the 1980s. Materials show the Ford Foundation's communication and collaboration with organizations like the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS) during a time when China underwent economic and political changes and shifting international relations. Foundation programming largely centered on education and research with specific focuses on economics education and training in China, educational exchanges between China and the U.S., law education, Chinese international relations, and research on the changes occurring in China.

The work of groups like the United States Committee on Economics Education and Research in China (CEERC) and the U.S. Committee on Legal Education Exchange with China (CLEEC) are documented in the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the chronology files Peter F. Geithner created and maintained during his tenure as Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program between 1981 and 1987. Files in the series span from 1981 to 1986.

Each chronology file in the series contains copies of the messages Geithner's office sent during a specific block of time. Within those blocks of time, the correspondence is arranged alphabetically, usually by the person to whom the correspondence is addressed but sometimes by the subject of the correspondence.
The chronology files contain Geithner's internal Ford Foundation communications as well as his messages to external individuals. Within the Foundation, Geithner frequently wrote to:
William Carmichael – Developing Countries Program Vice President
Franklin Thomas – Ford Foundation President
Enid C.B. Schoettle – International Affairs Program (IAP) Program Officer in Charge

Field Office Representatives as a group and several individually such as Lincoln Chen (New Delhi, India), Adrienne Germain (Dhaka, Bangladesh (Dacca)), Thomas Kessinger (Jakarta, Indonesia), Goran Hyden (Nairobi, Kenya), and John Gerhart (Cairo, Egypt)
Joan Carroll – Office of Personnel Services

External individuals include representatives from various foundations, research centers, universities, and governments. Numerous messages to representative of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS) show the Ford Foundation's increasing program interest regarding China.

The correspondence documents various DCP administrative and program activities like trips and visits, program reviews, program budgets, policies, hiring, requests for Ford Foundation support, and grants.
